paper_metadata.title: FAIMS Mobile: Flexible, open-source software for field research

software_pids.description: Permanent link to code repository for version 2.5

software_pids.location: page 1, Code metadata table; page 2 footnote 1

software_pids.description: Server installer script (wget and pipe to bash)

pid_graph_summary.calculation_rationale: Paper DOI (+1), Software repository URLs (+1), Multiple distribution URLs (+1). No author ORCIDs, no dataset DOIs, no sample PIDs, no project RAiD or vocabulary DOIs.

funding.verbatim_text: fees paid by our users for consultation, customisation, deployment, and support services
funding.notes: Revenue model for open-source software sustainability

data_availability.notes: Software publication - code is the primary research output, not data. No separate data availability statement.

code_availability.verbatim_text: Code metadata table and Software metadata table on page 1 provide comprehensive software availability information

computational_reproducibility.level_rationale: Complete source code provided on GitHub with comprehensive dependency specification (Java, Ruby, XML, SQLite, Spatialite, Javarosa, Antlr, Puppet, Apache, Imagemagick, God, Beanshell, gson, guice, Nutiteq, NativeCSS, Protobuf, Robotium). Compilation requirements specify Android Studio, Ubuntu 16.04, and Nutiteq license. Installation requirements specify Android 6+ and Ubuntu 16.04. However, no containerization (Docker/Singularity) or fully automated build environment provided.

files_present: Code metadata table specifies languages, tools, services
environment_specification.platform_details: Android Studio for mobile app compilation, Ubuntu 16.04 for server deployment, Android 6+ for mobile app execution

analysis_transparency.parameter_details: Software configuration through definition packets (XML, Beanshell, CSS) documented in Module Cookbook and Beanshell API
analysis_transparency.workflow_description: Development workflow documented in developer documentation (https://faimsproject.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/FAIMS/overview) and User to Developer guide (https://github.com/FAIMS/UserToDev)
analysis_transparency.alternative_analyses_description: Software publication - not applicable to alternative analyses

code_availability.machine_actionability_rationale: Multiple machine-actionable access methods: GitHub repository with version control, Google Play API, direct APK download, automated server installer script. Code can be cloned, compiled, and deployed programmatically. Well-structured metadata in tables parseable as structured data.
code_availability.licence_notes: Clearly stated in both Code metadata and Software metadata tables. Open-source license allowing modification and redistribution.
code_availability.notes: Exceptional software availability for 2018. Multiple distribution channels, comprehensive dependency documentation, extensive developer and user documentation. Software is actively maintained with version tracking.

author_contributions.notes: No explicit author contributions statement found in paper. SoftwareX papers in 2018 did not routinely include CReDIT taxonomy. Based on author order and affiliations: Ballsun-Stanton (first author, software developer), Ross (corresponding author, project lead), Sobotkova (methodological design), Crook (domain expertise).

conflicts_of_interest.notes: No conflicts of interest or competing interests statement found in paper.

ethics_approval.notes: Software development paper - no human or animal subjects. Ethics approval not applicable.

permits_and_authorizations.notes: Software development paper - no fieldwork or data collection requiring permits.

preregistration.notes: Software development paper published in 2018. Preregistration not applicable to software publications.

materials.description: Introductory video related to this article
materials.verbatim_text: An introductory video related to this article can be found online at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.softx.2017.12.006.

supplementary_materials.notes: Single supplementary video. Primary supplementary materials are the extensive documentation links and GitHub repositories listed in metadata tables.

references_completeness.notes: References include 6 DOIs out of 24 total references (25%). Many references are to URLs (perma.cc archived links), software repositories, and websites. For a 2018 software paper with many web resources, this is reasonable. References 1, 4, 7, 8, 10, 24 have DOIs.

data_fair.rationale: Software publication - no separate data to assess. Code availability assessed instead.

F1_globally_unique_persistent_identifier.rationale: No DOI for software itself. GitHub repository URL is persistent but not a formal PID. Repository is https://github.com/ElsevierSoftwareX/SOFTX-D-17-00021 which provides permanence through Elsevier archival, but lacks a citable DOI.

F2_data_described_with_rich_metadata.rationale: Exceptional metadata richness. Code metadata table and Software metadata table provide comprehensive structured metadata: version, repository URL, license, languages/tools, dependencies, compilation requirements, operating environments, documentation links, support contact, installation requirements, user manual links. Far exceeds typical software documentation.

F3_metadata_includes_identifier.rationale: Metadata tables include repository identifier (GitHub URL), Google Play package ID, version numbers. While not a DOI, identifiers are clearly specified and retrievable.

F4_indexed_in_searchable_resource.rationale: Software indexed in Google Play store, SoftwareX journal (indexed in Scopus/WoS), GitHub (searchable), and project website (fedarch.org). Multiple discovery pathways.

A1_retrievable_by_identifier_using_stand.rationale: Code retrievable via HTTPS from GitHub, Google Play API, and direct APK download. All use standard web protocols.

A1_1_protocol_open_free_universally_impl.rationale: HTTPS is open, free, and universally implementable. Git protocol for GitHub is also open and standardized.

A1_2_protocol_allows_authentication_auth.rationale: GitHub and Google Play support authentication/authorization where needed. Public repositories allow anonymous access. Authentication mechanisms available for private deployments.

A2_metadata_accessible_even_when_data_un.rationale: Metadata in published paper (SoftwareX) will persist even if repositories become unavailable. Paper DOI ensures metadata permanence. ElsevierSoftwareX repository provides archival guarantee.

I1_use_formal_accessible_shared_broadly_.rationale: Code written in Java, Ruby, XML, SQL - all formal, standardized languages. Build systems (Android Studio, Puppet) are industry-standard tools.

I2_use_vocabularies_following_FAIR_princ.rationale: No evidence of software ontologies or controlled vocabularies used in code documentation. Standard programming language keywords but no linked ontologies.

I3_include_qualified_references_to_other.rationale: References to dependencies are well-specified (Javarosa, Antlr, Spatialite, Nutiteq, etc.). Documentation links are qualified references. GitHub repository structure includes proper module dependencies.

R1_richly_described_with_attributes.rationale: Extensive attributes in metadata tables: version, languages, tools, compilation requirements, operating environments, dependencies, documentation links, support email. Multiple documentation resources (Cookbook, API docs, User guide).

R1_1_released_with_clear_accessible_data.rationale: GPLv3 license clearly stated in both Code metadata and Software metadata tables. License is well-known, accessible, and machine-readable.

R1_2_associated_with_detailed_provenance.rationale: Development history available through GitHub version control. Paper describes 5 years of development since 2012. Funding sources documented. Development process described in text.

R1_3_meet_community_standards.rationale: Follows software engineering best practices: version control (Git), semantic versioning (2.5, 2.5.20), standard license (GPLv3), comprehensive documentation, test framework (Robotium), standard build tools (Android Studio). Meets SoftwareX publication standards.

machine_actionability.rationale: Multiple machine-actionable interfaces: GitHub API for code access, Google Play API for distribution, automated installer script (wget and pipe to bash), structured metadata tables parseable as data, version control system enabling programmatic access. Software can be discovered, retrieved, installed, and deployed programmatically.

discipline_context.discipline_baseline: Software publication in archaeological informatics. Pre-FAIR4RS principles (published 2022). For 2018, this represents exemplary software publication practice.
discipline_context.research_type: Software development and deployment. Computational/infrastructure research.
discipline_context.context_rationale: Scored against 2018 expectations for software publications. Missing F1 (software DOI) reflects limited adoption of software citation principles pre-2019. Zenodo integration for software DOIs became common 2019-2020. Otherwise exceptional FAIR compliance for the era. If published in 2023, would expect Software Heritage or Zenodo DOI (F1) and structured citation.cff file.

recommendations: Mint a DOI for the software using Zenodo or Software Heritage (would add F1 point, achieving 14/15 = 93% FAIR)
Add software ontology terms (e.g., SoftwareOntology, CodeMeta) for I2 compliance (would achieve 15/15 = 100% FAIR)
Create citation.cff file in repository for machine-readable citation metadata
Consider FAIR4RS principles (published 2022) for future software releases

fair_assessment.overall_notes: Exceptional reproducibility infrastructure for a 2018 software publication. Comprehensive metadata, multiple access pathways, clear licensing, extensive documentation, version control, and automated deployment. Missing only software DOI (uncommon in 2018) and formal ontology integration. Represents best practice for software publication at time of writing.

extraction_notes: Software publication - data availability not applicable, code IS the primary research output
No ORCIDs found for any authors (2018 adoption in HASS was low, 17-24%)
No author contributions statement (not standard for SoftwareX in 2018)
No conflicts of interest statement (not standard for SoftwareX in 2018)
Exceptional software metadata tables provide machine-readable structured information
Multiple software distribution channels (GitHub, Google Play, direct download)
GPLv3 license supports reuse and modification
Funding section lists 11+ funding sources including government, universities, CSIRO, and user fees
References include perma.cc archived URLs for web resources (good practice for link persistence)
Computational reproducibility level: code_dependencies (full source + dependencies, but no containerization)
FAIR assessment: 13/15 (86.7%) - highly FAIR. Missing only software DOI and ontology terms.
Infrastructure quality significantly exceeds 2018 HASS discipline baseline
